import React from 'react'; import { Link } from 'react-router-dom'; import { motion } from 'framer-motion'; const Home = () => { // Animation variants const containerVariants = { hidden: { opacity: 0 }, visible: { opacity: 1, transition: { staggerChildren: 0.2, delayChildren: 0.3 } } }; const itemVariants = { hidden: { y: 20, opacity: 0 }, visible: { y: 0, opacity: 1, transition: { type: 'spring', stiffness: 100, damping: 10 } } }; const buttonVariants = { hover: { scale: 1.05, boxShadow: '0 10px 25px -5px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1), 0 10px 10px -5px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.04)', transition: { type: 'spring', stiffness: 400, damping: 10 } }, tap: { scale: 0.98 } }; return (

Santa Claus Problem Solver

This application demonstrates the Santa Claus Problem algorithm for fair allocation of presents to kids.

Restricted Assignment Case

The paper we worked on focuses specifically on the restricted assignment case of the Santa Claus Problem, where:

{[ <>Each present has a fixed intrinsic value - the same value for all kids who can receive it, <>Each kid can only receive certain presents - not all presents are compatible with all kids, <>The goal is to maximize the minimum happiness of any kid in the allocation ].map((item, index) => ( {item} ))}

This special case has important applications in resource allocation problems where resources have fixed values but can only be assigned to certain recipients.

Problem Description

In the Santa Claus Problem, we have a set of kids and a set of presents. Each kid has a different valuation for each present. The goal is to distribute the presents in a way that maximizes the minimum happiness among all kids.

In the restricted assignment case, each present has a fixed value for all kids who can receive it, and 0 for kids who cannot receive it.

Algorithm Approach

The algorithm uses a Configuration LP approach to find an approximate solution:

  • 1 Binary search for the optimal target value
  • 2 Classify presents as "big" or "small" based on values
  • 3 Build a bipartite graph and convert to a forest
  • 4 Create super-machines based on forest structure
  • 5 Round to an integral solution

); }; export default Home;
